This bugs me, because itâs WRONG.Â  English spelling is far from perfect, and there are a lot of complications, ambiguities, and irregularities, but there *are* rules.Â  Letâs take âghâ.Â  There are three ways it can be pronounced.Â  When followed by a vowel, it can only be pronounced as a hard âgâ as in âghostâ or âspaghettiâ.Â  When itâs word-final* or followed by a consonant, there are two possible pronunciations (yes, unpredictable).Â  It may either be silent as in âthroughâ or âdroughtâ or it may be pronounced as âfâ as in âenoughâ or âlaughâ.Â  So, by those rules, âfâ is not a possible pronunciation in âghotiâ.Â  Hard g is the only possible pronunciation

The âoâ in âwomenâ is an isolated irregularity involving an irregular noun.Â  In this context, of an âoâ followed by a single consonant and a vowel, the regular pronunciation is of a long âoâ, a short âoâ is also a possibility.Â  But definitely not a short âiâ

âTiâ can only be pronounced as âshâ when followed by another vowel, as in ânationâ (historically derived from âtyâ -> âtsyâ -> âsyâ -> âshâ; the first two steps occurred in the Latin -> French phase, the last in English).Â  In any other situation, the âtâ can only be pronounced as a regular âtâ, and the âiâ as a vowel dependent on surrounding context.Â  Being word-final, âeeâ is the only possible pronunciation.

So, that word would be pronounced as âgoateeâ, though one could possibly make an argument for âgotteeâ

*Or more precisely, morpheme-final, as suffixes like -ing can be added to words like âlaughâ without changing the pronunciation
